folder: Richmond Terrace & Van Name Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
2784 Richmond Terrace, at the S.W. corner of Van Name Avenue, showing the Captain David Van Name house, built in the 1850's. Captain David Van Name was one of the old vikings of the oyster trade. He was one of the first two men to plant oysters in American waters. Robinson's maps of 1898 and 1907 show the house to have been owned by the Staten Island Savings Bank. The view if westward.

September 28, 1924

By Wm. T. David through P. L. Sperr
title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Van Name Avenue

folder: Richmond Terrace & Van Name Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
2800, 2808, and 2814 Richmond Terrace, south side, between Van Name and Van Pelt Avenues, showing "Captains' Row," houses built by some of Staten Island's oystermen. No. 2800 belonged to J. Van Name from 1874 to 1898; to Sophie Van Name in 1907, and to J. H. Van Name in 1917. No. 2808 was, from 1874 to 1898, the P. Van Name house and, in 1907 the Thos. W. Butts house. No. 2814, known as "the Colonial" was built by Captain Garrett P. Wright. It was the Wright house from 1874 to 1898; the Louis Decker house in 1907, and the A. M. Decker house in 1917. Dates refer to maps on which the owners' names appear.

September 28, 1924

By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr
title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Van Name Avenue

folder: Richmond Terrace & Van Name Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1)
2760 Richmond Terrace, adjoining the S.E. corner of Van Name Avenue, showing the All Saints Protestant Episcopal
Church.
May 4, 1932
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same, at a later date.
June 17, 1937
P.L. Sperr
